What.Industry: Data Processing & Data Centers / Digital Assets Infrastructure
What.Niche: Industrial-scale Bitcoin mining and High-Performance Computing (HPC) data center development/hosting, primarily utilizing power capacity in Texas.
What.Description: Cipher Mining Inc. is an emerging technology company focused on the development and operation of industrial-scale data centers in the United States. Its primary activities include self-mining Bitcoin and providing High-Performance Computing (HPC) hosting services for large-scale customers, such as hyperscalers. The company strategically focuses on securing power capacity and developing data centers, particularly in areas like Texas, to capitalize on low-cost energy for its power-intensive operations.
What.Products: Self-mined Bitcoin (for proprietary reserve or sale), Data Center Hosting Services for High-Performance Computing (HPC) workloads (e.g., AI/ML), Ancillary Services participation in the power grid (e.g., ERCOT).
What.MarketPosition: A publicly traded Bitcoin miner and emerging HPC data center developer, positioning itself as a hybrid infrastructure company. It is a market leader in innovation, including in bitcoin mining growth, data center construction, and as a hosting partner to the world's largest HPC companies.

When.FoundedDetails: Founded as a development-stage company, which then merged with the Special Purpose Acquisition Company (SPAC) Good Works Acquisition Corp. to become publicly traded.
When.IPODate: The SPAC merger that made the company public occurred in 2021 (The specific date of the final de-SPAC transaction is often cited as August 27, 2021, though the first public trading under the CIFR ticker may vary slightly around that time).
When.KeyMilestones: Secured major data center sites in Texas (e.g., Odessa, Bear, Panther, Black Pearl, Colchis); Completed energization and full operation of key mining facilities (e.g., Black Pearl Phase I); Executed a transformative 10-year AI Hosting Agreement with Fluidstack and Google (approx. $3B contracted revenue); Executed a significant 15-year data center campus lease with Amazon Web Services (approx. $5.5B contracted revenue) to deliver 300 MW of capacity for AI workloads.
When.Acquisitions: Acquisitions or development agreements for key data center sites, such as the acquisition of Black Pearl Mining (late 2023) and securing majority ownership (~95%) in a joint venture to develop the 1-Gigawatt Colchis site in West Texas.
When.RecentEvents: The execution of major long-term HPC hosting contracts with Amazon Web Services and the development of the 1-Gigawatt Colchis site, signaling a significant strategic pivot and expansion into the high-performance computing data center sector.

Where.Headquarters: 1 Vanderbilt Avenue, Floor 54, Suite C, New York, NY 10017
Where.OperationalFootprint: Operations are primarily focused on industrial-scale data centers in Texas, where it leverages large-scale power capacity and competitive energy costs.
Where.GeographicPresence: Operates data centers in the United States, specifically across Texas (Odessa, Bear, Panther, Black Pearl, and the future Colchis site) for Bitcoin mining and HPC hosting.

How.BusinessModel: A hybrid operational model focused on developing and operating industrial-scale data centers. The company allocates its power capacity between two main functions: self-mining Bitcoin and hosting High-Performance Computing (HPC) workloads for third-party clients (hyperscalers/AI companies).
How.RevenueStreams: 1. **Self-Mining Revenue:** Bitcoin rewards earned from validating transactions on the Bitcoin blockchain. 2. **HPC Hosting Revenue:** Lease payments and service fees from large-scale contracts with clients for providing turnkey data center space and power for AI/ML workloads. 3. **Ancillary Services Revenue:** Revenue generated from participating in power grid ancillary services (e.g., ERCOT) by adjusting power consumption.
How.Products: Bitcoin (as a mined commodity), Data Center Capacity and Power (as a service).
How.Monetization: Monetizes its owned/developed power and data center infrastructure by either dedicating it to its proprietary Bitcoin mining operations or leasing it out for long-term, high-value HPC hosting contracts. Bitcoin mined can be held on the balance sheet or sold for operational liquidity.
How.CompetitiveAdvantages: Strategic access to large-scale, low-cost, and flexible power capacity in Texas; Vertically integrated approach to data center construction and operation; Early strategic pivot into high-value, long-term HPC hosting for Tier 1 hyperscalers (like AWS and Google), providing revenue diversification and stability; Experienced management team from finance, technology, and energy sectors.
How.MarketStrategy: Focus on securing and developing a large pipeline of power capacity (e.g., the 3.2 GW pipeline) in energy-rich, non-traditional locations in Texas; Optimize capital allocation between self-mining Bitcoin and high-margin, contracted HPC hosting; Continuous focus on operational efficiency and a low all-in electricity cost per Bitcoin mined.

Who.LeadershipTeam: Tyler Page (CEO), Will Iwaschuk (Co-President & Chief Legal Officer), Patrick Kelly (Co-President & Chief Operating Officer), Gregory Mumford (Chief Financial Officer).
Who.Founders: The company was formed by a team including Tyler Page, who had previous experience in digital assets and institutional finance (Bitfury Group, NYDIG, Stone Ridge, Goldman Sachs).
Who.InstitutionalOwnership: High institutional ownership is typical for a public company of this size. Major institutional holders often include large asset managers like The Vanguard Group, Inc. and BlackRock Fund Advisors (exact percentage fluctuates, but is substantial).
Who.MajorShareholders: Institutional investors such as The Vanguard Group and BlackRock; other major stakeholders may include original SPAC investors or large convertible note holders.
Who.BoardOfDirectors: The board of directors is composed of industry experts, typically including the CEO, representatives from the founding entities, and independent directors (specific names would require a deep dive into the latest proxy statement).
